body.p: To his excellency B Magoffin Governor of Ky

Your petitioner Jno H Kemper, would respectfully represent that he was fined before James T Ford Esq on the 9 day of July 1861. on a warrant for keeping a tipling house the sum of $20 -- ^for retailing^ He further represents that he was innocent of the charge and the same could only be proved against him by irresponsable witnesses who were greatly prejudiced against him. He also states that the whole affair was conceived and carried on by the prosecutor and witnesses against him altogether through malice, ^A remission of the fine is respectfully asked^. He positively alledges that he is innocent of the charge, this 25th Aug 1861,
Sworn to before me by Jno H Kemper this 25th Aug 1861.
James G Hutton J P C

I was attorney for Mr Kemper in the above cause and from the facts and the circumstances surrounding the same I am satisfied that Mr Kemper is innocent of having violated the Law and I really believe the fine ought to be remitted

I attended to the prosecution for the commonwealth against Mr Kemper & was so well satisfied from the manner of the prosecuters & witneeses ^that^ Mr Kemper ought not to suffer the penalties of the law I released the 30 percent due me as county attorney & I sincerly hope your excellency will remit the fine as I believe in Justice it ought to be done

John Hawkins ctty atto
For Floyd County

I was the Justice who tried Mr Kemper on the within charge and I give it as my opinion, that the whole affair was carried on through prejudis. In fact from what I could see mallice was the only element in the case. 25th Aug 1861
Jas T Ford J. P. F. C.

John H Kemper
To } Petition
Flody J. P.
Govener
